plist.p: Good morning, everyone. I'm Nicandro Durante, Chief Executive of British American Tobacco. And with me this morning is Finance Director, Ben Stevens. This morning, we'll be taking you through the half-yearly results. Due to the Olympics and certain disruptions to travel, we are changing the format to the previous years. We'll be doing our Q&A via conference call following the presentation when there will be the opportunity for you to ask questions.

And now, the headlines. I'm glad to report that we have delivered a good set of numbers against a difficult backdrop of global economic uncertainties, contracting markets, a tough comparison given the one-off benefits seen from Japan last year and significant currency headwinds. On a reported level, volumes, profits and margin were all up with exception of revenue which was flat.

However, the real story is in the constant organic numbers which show the underlying performance of the business. Organic volumes were down 0.6%, and if we strip out the Japan benefit, they would have grown slightly, up 0.1%. Constant organic revenue was up 4% and profit up 6%. GDBs continued to perform well at 4% with growth in all four brands. Again, excluding the Japan benefits, they would have grown nearly 6%.

The decline in industry volumes continues to moderate and underlying basis, volumes were down between and 1% and 1.5%. Excluding the impact of Japan, the group cigarette market share in its top 40 markets is essentially flat compared to the full year 2011 and is showing a growing trend in 2012. We continued to grow our share in premium. Adjusted EPS rose 7% to 102.4p, but in constant terms, would have grown 10%. And the board declared an interim dividend per share of 42.2p, up 11%. As is usual, the interim dividend has been set at one-third of last year's total dividend.

Let's now look at the brands. As I said, all four GDBs contributed to a good overall volume growth, up 4.4% at 112 billion at the half year. This growth was driven by the successful geographic rollout of our main innovation platforms, in particular the capsule market, where we have global leadership with a 52% share. In total, innovations were up an impressive 26%. And GDBs now represent one-third of group's volume. Also, we have a number of other international brands which, together with the GDBs, account for 53% of group volumes. In total, international brands were up 3% in the half year.

Looking at the brands individually, Dunhill volumes were up 3% despite the share loss following the price increase last year in South Korea. Excluding South Korea, Dunhill was up 11% with gains in Malaysia, Indonesia, Romania, South Africa, Nigeria, and the GCC as the brand continued to benefit from the rollout of innovations.

Kent volumes were 2% ahead as volume growth in Russia, Ukraine and Switzerland more than offset declines in Chile and Uzbekistan and a tough comparator from Japan. Excluding the one-off in Japan, the brand was up 7%.

Lucky Strike produced another excellent performance, up 19% driven by France, Germany, Spain and Argentina. Lucky strike is now the fastest-growing brand in Western Europe. Capsules are driving the share and volume gains.
Pall Mall was up 3% with strong growth in Pakistan, Russia and Romania, and gains in Germany and Canada. These more than offset the decline in Spain, Italy and Chile.

Looking at the volume and constant revenue on organic basis in more detail, volumes were down 0.6% and revenue was up more than 4%, implying continued good price and mix of around 5%. Higher volumes were recorded in a number of top 40 markets, including Pakistan, Vietnam, Canada, Chile, France, Switzerland, Ukraine, South Africa and the Middle East. Volumes and revenue in the Asia Pacific were flat against the strong prior year comparator, but went up nearly 3% and 5%, excluding the Japan one-off.

In the Americas, organic volumes were down 2% principally due to the market volume declines in Brazil and Mexico partially offset by growth in Canada and Chile. Organic revenue was up 2%. Western Europe volumes were down 4% mainly due to market contractions in Italy and Spain. However, strong pricing in the region led it to a 3% improvement in organic revenue. EEMEA volumes were 2% ahead, with the increases in the Middle East, South Africa and Ukraine. These, together with a strong pricing and product mix, resulted in impressive 13% increase in revenue.

At constant rate, each of the regions contributed to the group 6% growth in organic operating profit. Adjusted for Japan one-off sales, Asia-Pac profit at constant rates should have been up 10%. Strong performance in Japan, Malaysia, Pakistan and Vietnam, together with cost savings initiatives across the regions, contributed to the profit improvement. Profit in the Americas was up 3% mainly to the growth in Brazil and Chile, partially offset by a lower contribution from Mexico. This was more than offset by adverse currency movements resulting in a 2% drop in profit at current rates.

In Western Europe, despite the volume contraction caused by the economic turmoil, profit increased 2%. This was driven by good performance in Germany, Switzerland, Denmark, UK, France and Romania, partially offset by Italy and Greece. Despite the instability in some EEMEA markets, the region delivered an excellent 15% growth in profit at constant rates, mainly due to strong performances in Russia, Turkey, the GCC and South Africa.

Turning now to the regions in more detail, starting with Asia Pacific. Japan volumes were down following the significant one-off sales benefit last year. Share remains above 12%, up more than one percentage point over December 2010 exit share. Excluding the one-off effect, profit grew strongly during the period. In Australia, profit was up as a result of favorable exchange rates while the impact of lower volumes partially offset by cost savings and higher pricing.

In Indonesia, following the change in excise structure and consequent price increases, we de-listed a number of our tail brands. These, coupled with higher costs, resulted in lower volumes and profits. In Malaysia, we grew share, profits and volumes, and strengthened our leadership position mainly through the continuous strong performance of Dunhill. In South Korea, profit was in line with last year as our major competitor failed to increase prices. And in Vietnam, volume and share grew driven by Kent and State Express 555. Higher pricing and volumes resulted in good profit growth.

Now to the Americas. In Brazil, the market contracted following the recent excise-led price increase. However, GDB performance improved market share. Higher prices and an improved product mix resulted in good profit growth.

In Canada, industry volumes increased as a result of more moderate price and excise increases and a stable illicit trade. Market share was flat with good performances from du Maurier and Pall Mall. We remain leaders in both the premium and below-premium segments. Despite higher volume and lower costs, profits were down due to the continued downtrading.

In Mexico, following the sharp excise-led price increase in 2011, illicit trade has more than doubled over the last year and is now 15% of the market. Industry volumes declined substantially, but the market share was essentially flat against the full year. In Colombia an increase in organic volumes and savings from integration of Protabaco improved profit.

In Western Europe, despite the tough economic environment, overall market share was up with growth in the majority of the markets. This was mainly driven by the good performance of GDBs which were flat in a declining market.

Lucky Strike is doing particularly well. Fine Cut volumes grew strongly, up 7%, and share rose significantly versus the same period last year. Pall Mall is by far the largest Fine Cut brand in Europe. In Germany, volumes were stable. Our share grew in a declining market. Profit increased strongly as a result of higher margins and lower costs.

In France, a rising market share led to higher volumes. Coupled with improved margins, this resulted in good profit growth. In Italy, the market contract and our volumes declined as a result of the economic downturn. Market share was lower compared to the last year following declines in the tail brands.

Dunhill and Lucky Strike performed well. Despite an improved mix, price increase and cost savings, profit was lower. In Spain, profit was up driven by stabilization of the price environment and the continued growth of Lucky Strike. In Romania, Dunhill and Pall Mall contributed to an increasing profit, volumes and market share.

And finally, EEMEA, volumes in Russia were in line with last year. And compared to the full year, market share improved. Kent volumes were up 5%, drive an increase in our premium share to 50%, further strengthening our leadership position in the segment. Price increases, coupled with an improved product mix, resulted in a strong profit growth.

In Ukraine, a higher market share led to volume growth. The improvement in the product mix was offset by competitive pricing activities in the lower end of the market. These, together with increased marketing investments, resulted in a lower profit. Constant profit was higher in South Africa, this – following favorable pricing and increased volumes. Despite an increase in illicit trades, Dunhill and Peter Stuyvesant both posted strong performance.
In the GCC markets, good performance by Dunhill and Rothmans led to an increase in volumes and share. Higher volumes, improved margins and cost savings resulted in strong profit growth.

In Turkey, profit was up, helped by cost savings and higher margins and the excise-driven price increase taken last year. Volumes and market share declined as a result of main – declined mainly as a result of competitor price activities and volume losses on tail brands. However, successful government enforcement has seen a reduction in the levels of illicit trades.
This brings to the end of the regional review. I will now hand over to Ben.

Thank you, Nicandro, and good morning, everyone. As you know, currency headwinds during the first half impacted revenue by 4% and adjusted profit by 3%. The impact on EPS was also 3%. While we cannot predict exchange rates, many of our key currencies remain weak against sterling. So, if we translate the first half results at current spot rate, EPS would be reduced by a further 2%.

As you're all aware, our target is to improve our operating margin by 50 to 100 basis points each year. The one percentage point improvement in the first half means we're on target to deliver at the upper end of the range this year. All regions contributed to this growth. It was pleasing to see margin growth in Western Europe despite the extremely challenging operating environment and the additional costs associated with low ignition propensity cigarette paper regulation, which was not a factor in the first half of the prior year.

I'd like to point out that operating margin is usually flat in the first half by the timing of marketing investment. Nonetheless, we remain confident that we'll deliver at the upper end of the target for the full year.

Turning now to the income statement, adjusted profit from operations grew 3% to £2.839 billion. At constant currencies, growth was 6%. This reflects our continuing focus on cost management so that we achieved good flow through from our revenue growth. Restructuring costs were marginally higher than in the first six months of 2011. The main items were further costs associated with factory rationalizations in Australia, Germany and Argentina, Colombia integration costs and costs associated with other restructuring initiatives, including beginning to roll out a new operating model. And adjusted profit from operations grew 2% to £2.740 billion.

I'll cover net finance costs on the next slide. Despite the weakness in the Indian rupee, associates were 5% higher at £344 million. For the purposes of the adjusted earnings per share calculation, the adjusted contribution from associates is £32 million or 10% higher at £347 million. The adjusted contribution from Reynolds American was 9% higher at £219 million. At a constant rate, the increase was 7%. Once again, ITC has performed extremely well, with its adjusted contribution increasing by 12% to £122 million. At constant rates, the growth was a very impressive 27%. Profit before tax was 3% higher at £2.9 billion.

Net finance costs were down 9% or £22 million on the same period last year. The main driver was fair value changes on derivatives, although as you'll see both interest payable and investment income were favorable versus the same period last year. Our underlying tax rate was marginally below the 31% guidance for the six months and is below the rate of the same period last year. This reduction is primarily due to the geographic mix of profits across the group and by the anticipated similar rate for the full year.

Profit for the period rose 4% to £2.086 billion. And the non-controlling interest charge rose 15% to £157 million. The number of shares in issue reduced due to our continuing share buyback program, and this contributed to an adjusted earnings per share of 102.4%, an increase of 7% or 10% at constant currencies.

The main driver of adjusted earnings per share growth was operating profit which was up 6%. As flagged at the time of our 2011 full year results presentation, we are now facing a currency headwind and exchange rate of 3% adverse impact on performance. Strong performances by associates, together with the taxation, finance cost and share buyback elements that I've already addressed, all contributed to the 7% growth in earnings per share.

Moving on to cash flow, operating cash flow dropped by £485 million. This reduction is driven by two factors: firstly, the timing of working capital movements between the first and second half of the year, and I expect this to partially unwind by year-end; and secondly, higher capital expenditure as we fund our innovation strategy on the one SAP build.

Net interest and tax paid are lower primarily due to one-off payment relating to tax cases in 2011, which do not recur although the timing of tax payments in different jurisdictions is also factor. The main driver of higher income from associates is the Reynolds share buyback program. Overall free cash flow is £721 million, which is below the same period last year, and as I mentioned earlier, I expect this reduction to unwind before year-end.

Dividends paid increased by £103 million, and outflows due to the share buyback program are higher than last year as the program increased to £1.25 billion for the current year. Net investment activities relate to a small increase in our shareholding in the business in Bangladesh. All these resulted in a net outflow of £1.65 billion for the period.
And finally, net debt, which has increased by £1.5 billion since year-end, is very much in line with the same period last year.
That's the end of the presentation. And I'll hand back to Nicandro for the Q&A session.

Thank you, Ben. In summary, the underlying business continues to perform well despite the global economic uncertainty and the adverse impact of exchange rates. Our growth strategy continues to deliver constant organic revenue growth of 4%, reflects moderating volume declines, good GDB performance and continued good pricing momentum. The productivity element of our strategy is delivery as evidenced by the continued improvement in operating margin. Excluding the benefit of Japan, constant organic profit would have been up 8%.
At 102.4p, EPS is up 7%, excluding the currency impact would have grown 10%. These results are at upper end of our strategic metrics.
Thank you for watching this webcast. We will very shortly start with your questions. But before asking your question, please do not forget to state your name and firm. Thank you.
Thank you. And our first question comes from the line of David Hayes of Nomura. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Thank you. Good morning, gentlemen. Three from me, if I can. Just firstly on Brazil, obviously it looks like with the Americas volumes – the volumes are holding up pretty well there. Just wondered whether you can be a little bit more detailed on what you're seeing in terms of, I guess, downtrading and the illicit trade control and at minimum price points, and then competitor reaction as to the price increase that you took back in April.

Secondly, on Indonesia, can you just be a little bit more specific on or to remind us maybe of when the de-listing started with the local brands? Just trying to get a feel for when that lapse, whether that started early in the first half or whether that was more recent.

And then finally, just a bit more broadly, you probably saw one of your competitors a couple of weeks ago also was talking quite a lot of detail about the development of the reduced-harm next-generation products, which they're saying they're going to be commercially launching over the next two to three years. I just wonder whether you can give us an update on where BAT are with that side of the research and development and whether you'll be confident of having similar kind of progress in that timeframe. Thanks very much.

Well, David, let me start with Brazil. In terms of Brazil, we had an excise change – the change in excise structure in May this year. We went for a price increase and it was followed by the competition. In terms of one of the outcomes of this new structure – this change in excise tax, as I said in the full year, was the introduction of minimum price. And the volume that goes through the formal trade, it looks like that the competition is abiding by the minimum price.

So, it's good – it's a good sign that things are moving in the right direction because usually one who take a price increase of above 20%, that was the case, was around 21%. You have a surge in illicit trades and you haven't seen this happening in the last couple of months in Brazil. That's a good signal that it's working. So, that's the first point.

So, numbers in Brazil, I cannot be very specific about Brazil because they are publishing the results in one week or so, but it looks good. In terms of Indonesia, we had a change in excise legislation and had to – lifted the price of our low-price brand portfolio, and we took advantage to de-list some of the brands. So it was the beginning of this year. But the good news in Indonesia is that part of this loss was offset by some new brand introductions such as at Dunhill Mild Kretek. That is the most successful launch of international brand in Indonesia. The brand was launched at the end of March in a very good price position and the brand has been growing. It's very early days, but in three months, it has reached already 0.5% market share in Indonesia. So, this is good news. But in terms of de-lists and raising prices of the local brands, raising prices of local brands has started the end of last year, de-listing started this year.

Going for the third question about the reduced-harm products, well, let me tell you, our work in this area is very well-known. We have been actively investigating the opportunity to develop reduced harm of our products for some time. And we set up Nicoventures to investigate the technology in this area. And as you know we, talk about this, about the full year. We are making good progress. But personally, I would prefer to wait for something tangible before making any ambitious predictions. So we have to wait and see.

But there are lot of work being done in this area. We work with – in Southampton in our R&D with linear (26:52) research on the measurement of development cigarette toxicants. We work to investigate in the potential for reduced toxicants, smokeless products. And we had work, as I said, in non-tobacco nicotine products. And there are lot of work in this area. But I'm not in a position to make any predictions of launches because it has to have approval of the health organization in the country. So, it is a long way to go, but we are quite well advanced in this area as well.
Okay. Thank you. That's great. Thank you very much. Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Erik Bloomquist of Berenberg Bank. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Hi. Good morning. Erik Bloomquist, Berenberg. Could you discuss what drove the approximate £450 million negative working capital swing? I mean, you talked about it in broad terms, but is it really primarily driven by the SAP preparation because it seems like on a year comparable six-month basis, it seems unlikely that will reverse? So, if you could talk about that in more detail.

And then, secondly, it sounded like from the interview this morning, that BAT is not particularly optimistic on the outlook for the plain packaging challenge in Australia. Could you update us on that and then also what you're seeing – what you expect to the WTO challenge and the UK consultation on plain packaging? Thank you.

Okay. Good morning, Erik. It's Ben here. The increase in working capital is primarily excise-related stock movement. So, we've got the introduction of pictorial health warnings in the GCC, so we built stock for that. And some of that also went into trade there. And also, we've got a price increase in Russia in the middle half of this year which normally happens at the start of the year. So, those are the two major changes on working capital. And for those reasons, we expect them to reverse in the full year results.

Regarding plain packaging, we are waiting for the outcome of the court case of Australia. And as you are aware, there is a consultation in UK that has been postponed one month for – up to August 10. As expect, we are submitting our reviews to the government on that one. Let me be clear, BAT is not against the regulation. We just – in favor of regulation, that evidence-based. And we will – that we think we will meet the public health goals. So, I don't see that plain packaging falls in this category. And BAT would be challenging any legislations in this area whenever they appear.
Regarding WTO, well, we are waiting for the outcome. There are some countries that are challenged in this regulation at the WTO arena. And we are waiting for the outcomes of that.
Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jon Fell of Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Hi, everybody. Couple of things. First of all, Ben, I think you mentioned in your Cantos interview that you'll be expecting CapEx to go up a little bit over the next few years, partly SAP. But I'm just interested to see as well that you need more machinery to sort of back up the innovation effort. Can you talk a bit more about why that's necessary? I mean, I have an impression that innovation was something that you are already putting a lot of resource behind. So, I was slightly surprised to see that you need to wrap that up still further.
My second question was on the Philippines. Can you just update us where we've got to with potential changes in the excise regime there?

Yeah. Good morning, Jon. Two of the reasons I said in the Cantos interview, I mean, CapEx, the whole of the SAP program will obviously push CapEx up. So, I've guided people towards a sort of ongoing CapEx level for the next couple of years. Gross CapEx, this is of around £700 million.

I mean innovation will result in marketing spend being transferred into CapEx. So, I was really just trying to highlight the fact that some of the marketing spend that was traditionally in operating profit does move into CapEx simply because we do as we roll out very significant innovations, we need to spend money on machinery. And obviously, we've got a lot of very significant innovations in the top draw. At the moment we're currently rolling out innovations we have around the world because we believe that we've got to take the benefit of innovations we've got before we actually move on. But there's more innovations to come and with those innovations will come some increases in CapEx.

In the case of Philippines, as you are aware there is a proposal from the Philippines government to change the regulation on excise and this change of regulation has a lot of components. One is a huge increase in excise level, and one of the components is to create a lot of playing field in Philippines that we don't have today. We are supporting this change of regulation there. It has been approved in the lower house. Now, it's going for a vote in the upper house and we are waiting for the outcomes, but we are supporting the bill because it just allow us to play in Philippines in the same – with the same tools of the competition, so we are very supportive of the potential change of the legislation in excise.
Do you know when the vote in the upper house is going to be?

I think that – as far as I'm aware, we can be – I can be more precise with you later, but as far as I'm aware, the vote should come before the end of this year. We are expecting the beginning of quarter four, but I can be more precise than that after the conference call.
Thanks very much.
Okay.
Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Rogerio Fujimori of Credit Suisse. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Hi, it's Rogerio Fujimori here from Credit Suisse. Hi, Nicandro. I think you referred to in your opening remarks about Global Drive Brands and your international brands accounting for about 52% of group volumes. I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the actions that you just taken to improve your competitive position for the actions taken regarding the tail brands, particularly in markets like Turkey, Italy, I think you already addressed Indonesia. But – yeah, any color on the tail brands would be appreciated. Thank you.

Rogerio, as you said, the GDBs now is at one-third of our volume and international brands plus GDBs are 53% of our volume, which doesn't mean that we don't support some of our local brands. There are larger number of local brands that are very important for our portfolio and then we support those brands. They are fundamental in places like Canada, like Brazil or Turkey and so on and so forth. But there are some of the brands in the tail brands that we don't support them, and we try to migrate these, not a normal migration, but we expect that there is cannibalization of these brands for the Global Drive Brands and international brands. So, there are element of local brands that we are very supportive with.

In terms of what's going on in the markets, it's market by market. And when you look at Indonesia, for example, we thought that some of the local brands, they are not strong enough to remain in the market, and with the change in legislation. So, we decided to move for brands like Dunhill. That's part of our strategy. And in Turkey, we keep supporting some of the local brands such as Tekel 2000 because we think that there is some equity in the brand. But – so, it's market by market, Rogerio.

Thank you, Nicandro. I just have one quick question to Ben on – you mentioned about margin expansion in the full year close to the upper end of the targeted range. I was just wondering if you could please talk about marketing spending as a percentage of sales for the full year. Do you still plan for the same level versus last year?

Yeah. I mean, in terms of operating margin, we always have a higher operating margin in the first half than we do in the second half because marketing spend tends to be skewed towards the second half of the year. We're continuing to invest in marketing, so you'll see marketing spend as a sort of very normal trend in 2012.
So, similar to last year?
Of what we spend more in marketing each year as the business grows.
No. I mean, as a percentage of sales?
Yeah. I mean, there's nothing unusual happening in marketing spend.
Okay. Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of James Bushnell of Exane BNP Paribas. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Thank you and good morning. Two questions, please. You've spoken or at least spoken in the release about the various moving parts in the Americas division. You obviously can't talk too much about Brazil and the minorities' growth you suggest has been reasonably strong. Could you perhaps talk about how you see those moving parts developing over the remainder of the year and whether you'd expect better like-for-like profit growth in H2 than you had in H1 in the Americas? So, that's my first question.

And my second question, you're also mentioning a more positive development in South Africa which seems to be an improvement in at least on last year's trends. How do you see things playing out there over the next year or so? Thanks very much.

Okay. Just on Americas. We had in Mexico an excise gain last year. So, Americas profit is depressed by that. The underlying growth in America excluding that is about 9%. So, I think the performance from Americas for the full year will certainly be stronger than the half year.

Regarding South Africa, yes, illicit trade has grown in South Africa. If you look at to the first half of this year against the same period of last year, has grown 4.5 points. And despite of that, because of the economic, in terms of disposable income in the country, unemployment and GDP growth, overall volume in South Africa is up. Industry volume mix, we predicted that's going to be around 4% up this year against 2011, and our volumes are up as well. We have a very good position so far. We are maintaining our very strong position in term of market share. Peter extends and Dunhill especially, and we're extremely well in premium, and this has been driven the volume share and profit growth.

But the main issue that we have there is the growth of illicit trades, and I see this is an issue but I see as an opportunity as well. If you – the government enforces legislation and break it down, we have a huge opportunity there. We are playing nowadays in 80% – 72%, 73% of the market only.
Okay. Great. Thank you very much.
Our next question comes from the line of Chris Wickham of Oriel Securities. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Well, I was wondering if you can give us a bit more detail on your performance in the Middle East or GCC. And the second thing is just going back to the comments and with your reply to Erik and talking about science-led regulation which you mentioned on the interview. I mean, I was just wondering when you're talking about science-led, how realistic that is given where we are, or whether you saw any opportunity if we were moving in that direction to actually see some reverses in some of the things which haven't really had that impact on volumes. I'm thinking particularly about display bans which are more ubiquitous than obviously any plain packaging so far.

Talking a little bit about the Middle East, we have a very, very good performance in the Middle East in the first half of this year. And you take our position in places like Saudi, Dunhill's performance has been fantastic. The growth of market share behind Dunhill and our growth in the Middle East, mainly Saudi, that's the main market in Middle East, has been fantastic.

The downside of the Middle East is that we still have some countries going through some issues in terms of political instability. But overall, the performance in the Middle East is very, very strong. We have been growing. Volume, share and profit for the last – at least four to five years is very strong.
But remembering also that there's a stock bill in the Middle East as well ahead of the pictorial health warnings, but underlying performance is still very, very strong.
Yeah. The underlying performance is, forgetting a little bit the stock bills as Ben just highlighted, the performance is very strong. Growing share, volume and profit.

Talking about science-led regulation that we have highlighted in several times and which is our mantra, the reality that if you look at what's going on around United States with the FDA and the kind of legislation that is under discussion is pretty much – we hope that the signal is that it's pretty much science-led.

And I think that it's a good development for the industry. That's something that you have – every time that we engage with regulators, we try to get the message through. So, it's very difficult to be precise of you how it's going to be the development that come in one, two, three or four years. But I think that with the leadership of FDA in this area and the way that things are moving, I'm – I think that we are moving at the right direction.
Do you think there's any scope than to see any regulation reverse if that is set as the standard?
I find it difficult, but it's very difficult to predict. I was going to hope the next five to 10 years, but I find it difficult.
Okay. Thanks.
Our next question comes from the line of Adam Spielman of Citi. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Thank you. Can ask two questions? First of all, as far as I can tell from the press release, organic profit in Australia and Canada was flat or slightly down, and I believe it was also – that was the same case in the second half of last year. So, I'm wondering when we can expect to see profit growth in those countries or whether you feel that the combination of high prices and increasing illicit in Australia actually means to say that profit has probably got about as far as it can go in real inflation adjusted term, so that's one question.

The next question, you've alluded a couple of times to the SAP rollout, and my stand – my understanding is that it's going to be implemented first in Malaysia in September. But I was wondering if there was more detail you could give on this about how you think it's progressing and sort of how fast you intend to roll this out and, really, any color you can give. Thank you.

Okay. Profits in Australia were up in terms of currency, but essentially flat in constant currency terms, and that's really the development of a ultra-low price segment in Australia. There has been a lot of discounting there over the last year or two.

In terms of SAP rollout, yeah, we've – what you do with SAP is firstly you define your standard processes, you build the organization structure you want. Then you put SAP onto the back of those processes. So, all of that's been done. And now we're actually putting the very first instance of SAP into Malaysia. So, we've tested it there, very good news in the test in the sense that the pilot model worked very, very well. Number of changes we have to make to the business in Malaysia to standardize it with the new VAT standards, so that's going in in quarter three of this year. And then after that we'll carry on the rollout probably with Australia next.

The same time that we're doing Malaysia, we're also doing our central treasury functions here in the in-house cash modules of SAP. So, it's quite a big September for us in terms of the first actual implementation of SAP. And assuming that those are successful, then we'll carry on rolling it out around the world.

Fine. Just coming back to the question on Australia and Canada, when would it be reasonable to expect profit to start growing in those two markets? Would you – I mean, should we assume that the worst is over and we can get back to the previous trends we've seen, or would you expect discount to continue basically preventing growth in those two markets?

Adam, Nicandro speaking. I think that's very difficult to predict the next years in terms of profit delivery for those two markets, but I'm optimistic. And if we look at Canada, let's start from Canada, and we had some – as you remember in the last two conference calls that we had, we were discussing the overall share decline in Canada. And the good news coming from Canada is that if you look at the first half of this year against the second half of last year, so six months against six months period, the share has gone up strongly. So, the market is coming back, and we have very good developments with our brands and premium brands. We have the leadership in the premium segment and below premium.
